Back to the original tweet for this thread. The crypto community lives on the belief that there won’t be a “run on the bank” and that market participants will only convert to fiat as & when they need fiat. This is ironically in stark contrast to why Bitcoin was born in 2008!
Unless BTC & ETH can hit new highs soon, I believe we will see somewhat of a 2014 era bear market cycle. BTC & ETH are effectively acting as the reserve currency for the crypto industry.

The problem really comes in when the net monthly sales of crypto to fund mining and operations for over 3500 projects/companies exceeds the net fiat entering the market. The current bear market cycle means that you need to sell more crypto to get the same amount of cash out.

So every month they need to sell a little bit of crypto to pay the bills. That works well in a bull market. In a bear market, not so much. Essentially the ecosystem of innovation is funded by the fiat that has entered the system or is available when bills need to be paid.

Bitcoin was designed as a system to take on the big banks and fractional reserve system. What I’m seeing now is that a large number of funded crypto projects are only holding crypto and their runways are fluctuating every day.

bitcoin is a user currency, value is measured by the market. miners & devs can change - in the case of miners, they cease acting as a bitcoin miner if they mine an airdrop/altcoin. the "dev vs miner balance of power" typification is an inaccurate oversimplification in my view.

only the market can fork Bitcoin. we saw empirical evidence for this with B2X, BCH, BCD, SBTC, BCX and others. basically all metrics stayed with Bitcoin - miners can only temporarily unprofitably bootstrap spinoffs, and hope for a market to buy them.

The trick is to have a plan for the worst case without completely screwing up the common case. Case in point: transaction propagation in Bitcoin requires altruism. It's not incentivized in the protocol. Trying to make that worst-case proof would add pointless complexity.
